abstract: Home Depot was scrambling last night to save the sale of its wholesale unit to a consortium of private equity firms, lowering its asking price by about $1.2 billion from the original $10.3 billion it agreed upon, people involved in the talks said.

lead_paragraph: Home Depot was scrambling last night to save the sale of its wholesale unit to a consortium of private equity firms, lowering its asking price by about $1.2 billion from the original $10.3 billion it agreed upon, people involved in the talks said.

headline.main: Home Depot Said to Cut Price to Try to Save Sale of Unit
headline.print_headline: Home Depot Said to Cut Price to Try to Save Sale of Unit

abstract: Home Depot was scrambling Thursday night to save the sale of its wholesale unit to a consortium of private equity firms, lowering its asking price by about $1.2 billion from the original $10.3 billion it agreed upon, according to The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Home Depot was scrambling Thursday night to save the sale of its wholesale unit to a consortium of private equity firms, lowering its asking price by about $1.2 billion from the original $10.3 billion it agreed upon, according to The New York Times.

headline.main: Home Depot Scrambles to Save Sale of Unit

abstract: Negotiations over the fate of Home Depot‘s professional supply unit are likely to drag on through the weekend as financing of the $10.3 billion deal remains up in the air, people briefed on the matter told DealBook. Bankers and lawyers are expected to keep battling over whether the banks in the deal can withdraw their financing commitments, in what one person told The New York Times was “the most expensive game of chicken you’ve ever played.”
lead_paragraph: Negotiations over the fate of Home Depot‘s professional supply unit are likely to drag on through the weekend as financing of the $10.3 billion deal remains up in the air, people briefed on the matter told DealBook. Bankers and lawyers are expected to keep battling over whether the banks in the deal can withdraw their financing commitments, in what one person told The New York Times was “the most expensive game of chicken you’ve ever played.”

headline.main: A Delay in the Home Depot Battle Royale
